CORRECTION
Due to a printer's error the following appeared in the last issue of
the NEWS-LETTER under an editorial headed, "College Boys Will Be
College Boys:
"People everywhere humor the college man. The Baltimore public is no exception to this rule and look upon interclass quarrels with
disfavor." This should have read, ". . . and does not look upon interclass quarrels with disfavor."
The NEWS-LETTER regrets this error.

DANGER: GO SLOWLY
The Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences announces the indefinite suspension of a member of the Sophomore Class for participation in the interclass tussles which preceded the sophomore banquet last
Monday and caused the arrest, and subsequent release, of over a dozen
men. The announcement has stunned members of the lower classes
and has brought further interclass activity to a temporary stand-still.
Rumbles of indignation are apparent on the campus, freshmen joining
forces with the second-year men long enough to voice their disapproval.
Disapproval is to be expected; indignation is harmless. But when
leaders of the Sophomore Class threaten a "sympathy strike" matters
assume a graver aspect. Go slow, men! You are on dangerous ground.

"What do you think of the
plan of the Vassar students
to mark their professors at
the end of each year?"
(1) Dr. John H. Latane,
Dean: "In the long run, I
think the opinion of college
students about their professors is pretty accurate; but
the public opinion of the student body about any professor at any given time is of
very little value, for the reason that students are very
frequently carried away by
prejudices or by temporary
irritation over some action
which they may later realize
to be entirely just. I doubt,
therefore, whether the proposed system is of any
value."
(2) Dr. John C. French,
Associate Professor of English :"On the whole, it seems
to me that students are good
judges of their professors.
This, however, is only true
when the judgment is based
upon a consideration of the
professor's methods and of
the difficulty of his subject,
rather than upon the students' personal whims and
prejudices. A tactful handling of the matter would
make it really valuable."
(3) Ernest A. Strathman,
student: "It seems a •logical
step in the development of
student government. We
should have something to say
about the men we study under; and the Vassar girls'
plan seems practicable."
(4) Parker C. Williams,
Hopkins representative in
Southern Oratorical Contest:
"A novel idea, indeed. The
results of such a plan would
probably be helpful, but at
the present time at Hopkins
it seems impracticable."
(5) Paul Ives, former Editor Black and Blue Jay: "I
think that the scheme might
prove useful if the votes of
the students would carry any
weight. However, it is doubtful that the ordinary undergraduate is sufficiently equip.ped to be a good judge of the
scholastic merits of the professors."

DANGER: GO SLOWLY
The Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences announces the indefinite suspension of a member of the Sophomore Class for participation in the interclass tussles which preceded the sophomore banquet last
Monday and caused the arrest, and subsequent release, of over a dozen
men. The announcement has stunned members of the lower classes
and has brought further interclass activity to a temporary stand-still.
Rumbles of indignation are apparent on the campus, freshmen joining
forces with the second-year men long enough to voice their disapproval.
Disapproval is to be expected; indignation is harmless. But when
leaders of the Sophomore Class threaten a "sympathy strike" matters
assume a graver aspect. Go slow, men! You are on dangerous ground.
